Endpoint_ID from URL

Change-Id: I1e7a9b3af7e172079e721da584153e8ee4ab5f1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/44/199844/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== Map URL to Endpoint =================== `bp url_to_endpoint <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/url-to-endpoint>` Allow the lookup of athe endpoint ID for an URL hosted on the endpoint. Problem Description =================== Since a server knows its Hostname, but not its assigned ID, prior to registering with Keystone, interacting with policy should be based on the URL of the endpoint, and not the endpoint ID. However, the server has no way to fetch the policy by URL. Allow the server to lookup up the endpoint ID from a requested URL. It can later use this value to uniquely identify itself without requiring an additional configuration option. Proposed Change =============== Add a new query parameter for fetching the endpoint_id that returns the endpoint record for any URL hosted under the endpoint. `GET /endpoints?suburl=<encodedURL>` Alternatives ------------ Store and fetch Policy by URL. That can lead to ambiguity if the URL does not match. Security Impact --------------- These APIs themselves will have not effect on security. Their use will enable the use of Dynamic Policy in OpenStack, but that is out of the scope of this spec. Notifications Impact -------------------- Any notifications that are currently emitted for endpoint policy will continue to be emitted unchanged. Other End User Impact --------------------- Only intended use for this it to fetch policy, but there is no reason it cannot have a wider aplicability. It allows the endpoint to have a discoverable identity separate from service user, whichmight be used for multiple endpoints. Performance Impact ------------------ No change from existing API performance. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Primary change will be that, when creating an endpoint, the installer can add the URL to the Service configuration file prior to starting the service, and know that the value set therein will be used for policy fetches. Developer Impact ---------------- Should require a change to the policy SQL driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Adam Young ayoung@redhat.com Samuel de Medeiros Queiroz samuel@lsd.ufcg.edu.br Work Items ---------- Should be done all in one patch Dependencies ============ No external dependencies. Documentation Impact ==================== API will need to be documented References ========== Dynamic Policy topic in gerrit. https://adam.younglogic.com/2014/11/dynamic-policy-in-keystone/

commit_message:
query configuration via web API

Change-Id: I147893412500c8fbe59d306052f73da1acba0f97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/26/186926/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== Query Configuration =================== `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/query-config>`_ Provide an API to expose Keystone configuration values to remote services. Problem Description =================== As we move from V2 to V3, and as we implement dynamic policy, we find that there as certain pieces odf information that the Keystone server has that other services need in order to make smart decisions. When handling a V2 verion token, we do not know the default domain. When enforcing policy we do not know the admin domain. Both these values are in the configuration file. Proposed Change =============== Create an API that exposes a limited subset of the configuration values from the keystone server. Limit the values returned by a whitelist. Alternatives ------------ A centralized Configuration server could post the vbalues for both Keystone and the other services to use. This has been discussed, but is deemed too heavy weight for just this use case. Depending on a config server would increase the footprint for minimal deployments. Security Impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? Nonoe of the sensitive values from the config file would be whitelisted. No tokens would be exposed. * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? The information would be used when processing tokens. A hacked value would allow a service to treat a non-admin token as an admin token. However, to perform an attack like this requires DNS poi\soning, and would lead to many other more viable attacks first. * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? No change in the use of either cryptography or hashing. * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? No. Instead, the value would be used in expanding out Token data, and thus used by other serivces attempting to determin access control. * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. No. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. No. Notifications Impact -------------------- No notifications would be modified by this change. Other End User Impact --------------------- All interactions would be via the API. Performance Impact ------------------ No performance impact. The change would potentially increas the number of calls upon Keystone, but the amolunt would be minimal compared with token validations. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? One configuratuion option, which would be the list of whitelisted values reported byt the config API. * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? Immediately after merge. * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? No new binary Developer Impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other backends would implement the feature is required. Any developer attempting to performaoperations with V2 tokens should use the data returned by this aapi to set the default Domain. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Adam Young ayoung ayoung@redhat.com Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- The should be implmented in a single patch with unit tests. Follow on work in the auth plugins would allow other services to query this API. Dependencies ============ No new dependencies, Only oslo.config. Documentation Impact ==================== The new API will have to exist in the guide. Policy engine will be able to use this new API to enforce POlicy for the Admin domain. References ========== `Dynamic Policy <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147651/>`_

commit_message:
Remove designate support

It was broken, thus it was impossible that anyone was actually using it.
We do not have a plan for v1/v2 compat support yet, and it's a hard one.
SO - rather than leaving a broken thing in the tree which was not
possible to use, or fixing it and then having a half-baked thing which
people might actually start using, pull it out pending someone stepping
up and caring about it.

Change-Id: I390494fee8c6c7fb5ddde2ce47e7eb598ad5e08b

commit_message:
Image meta: treat legacy vmware adapter type values

Ensure that legacy metadata vmware_adaptertype values are
treated correctly. This value could have been set as "" and there
are existing deployments that use that.

Closes-bug: #1506465

commit_message:
Use fake server name instead of id when testing "server_name" param.

"server create" command takes a server name parameter. The server id is
generated by openstack.

When we intended to pass a server name to the unit tests of "server create"
command, we passed server id. It won't be any problem because the fake
server id is also a string, but we should pass a fake server name because
we have a string to fake one.

Change-Id: I9944f0ea2a6c457e4fad8215a54778bca08965ab

commit_message:
Use oslo_config PortOpt type for port options

The oslo.config>=2.6.0 library provides new PortOpt type to validate
a range of port.

Sample config file has been generated using "tox -egenconfig".

Add boot-server-from-volume-and-resize for nova benchmark

Added boot-server-from-volume-and-resize for nova benchmark.

Partially-Implements: blueprint benchmark-scenarios-for-nova
Change-Id: Ib24022ff975dc7e02fd4469ed7bf796e16878eb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/88/240788/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import ddt@ddt.ddt @ddt.data({"confirm": True, "do_delete": True}, {"confirm": False, "do_delete": True}) @ddt.unpack def test_boot_server_from_volume_and_resize(self, confirm=False, do_delete=False): fake_server = object() flavor = mock.MagicMock() to_flavor = mock.MagicMock() scenario = servers.NovaServers(self.context) scenario._boot_server = mock.MagicMock(return_value=fake_server) scenario.generate_random_name = mock.MagicMock(return_value="name") scenario._resize_confirm = mock.MagicMock() scenario._resize_revert = mock.MagicMock() scenario._resize = mock.MagicMock() scenario.sleep_between = mock.MagicMock() scenario._delete_server = mock.MagicMock() fake_volume = fakes.FakeVolumeManager().create() fake_volume.id = "volume_id" scenario._create_volume = mock.MagicMock(return_value=fake_volume) volume_size = 10 scenario.boot_server_from_volume_and_resize( "img", flavor, to_flavor, volume_size, min_sleep=10, max_sleep=20, confirm=confirm, do_delete=do_delete) scenario._create_volume.assert_called_once_with(10, imageRef="img") scenario._boot_server.assert_called_once_with( "img", flavor, block_device_mapping={"vda": "volume_id:::1"}) scenario.sleep_between.assert_called_once_with(10, 20) scenario._resize.assert_called_once_with(fake_server, to_flavor) if confirm: scenario._resize_confirm.assert_called_once_with(fake_server) else: scenario._resize_revert.assert_called_once_with(fake_server) if do_delete: scenario._delete_server.assert_called_once_with(fake_server, force=False)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-08 06:21:18.000000000', 'files': ['dragonflow/neutron/plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow/commit/2867f3c697df8a77646da41e52909ccd34880fbc', 'message': "Prevent DBError caused by wrong param passed to get_security_group

Previously, in update_port() we would call _get_port() to get a copy

This original_port value is in the form of a sqlalchemy object and the method
update_security_group_on_port() uses the original port value to populate
update_port['security_groups'].

In our case, we'd later pass this value to get_security_groups and it would

"}]
commit_message:
Prevent DBError caused by wrong param passed to get_security_group

Previously, in update_port() we would call _get_port() to get a copy
of the original port before we actually updated it.

This original_port value is in the form of a sqlalchemy object and the method
update_security_group_on_port() uses the original port value to populate
update_port['security_groups'].

In our case, we'd later pass this value to get_security_groups and it would
give us an error of: DBError because we were passing a
neutron.db.securitygroups_db.SecurityGroupPortBinding rather than an id.

Change-Id: Ia311647608781c00448a2f9c1af1c58a41270e2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/02/242802/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: original_port = self.get_port(context, id)

commit_message:
Handle VM shutdown case

This patch adds specific handling for local VM shutdown, in
this case OF port is deleted from OVS and reported to all the
applications.
The relevant applications find the appropriate logical port and
delete the relevant flows.
When VM is restarted the flows are re-added as part of the specific
application.

Future enhancment would be to only handle port status updates
in one application (including PACKET_IN) and any other OF protocol
messages and dispatch this to all the registered applications, this
can be done in future patch.

Closes-Bug: #1512713
Closes-Bug: #1513072
Change-Id: If24ed730d3b3808f07c3c187f045d9907e1336c1

commit_message:
Port vmware datastore to Python 3

* _filter_datastores(): replace filter() with list comprehension
  to get a list on Python 3.
* tox.ini: add test_vmware_datastore to Python 3.4.

Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-python3

commit_message:
Revert "Register FWaaS resources to quota engine"

This reverts commit 28948f6559711a0d861fa76f3adf65cda22768fb

Firewall tests in gate-tempest-dsvm-api are failing at a
pretty decent rate since 11/4 and they are over-quota fails,
so I suspect this is the culprit.

Change-Id: Ia4d6b9a65acd1111a050dc73b63a1f0ce619cb55
Closes-Bug: #1513280

commit_message:
[config-ref] Initial structure for RST migration

This patch provides the sphinx configuration and a basic index.rst to
get started with the configuration reference RST migration.

Change-Id: Ide09e553e5ee469ec7573471613e2f2dc271fa5c
Implements: blueprint config-ref-rst

added_lines: .. meta:: :description: This guide targets OpenStack Architects for architectural design :keywords: Architecture, OpenStack ================================= OpenStack Configuration Reference ================================= Abstract ~~~~~~~~ This document is for system administrators who want to look up configuration options. It contains lists of configuration options available with OpenStack and uses auto-generation to generate options and the d escriptions from the code for each project. It includes sample configuration files. .. warning:: This guide is a work-in-progress. Contents ~~~~~~~~ .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 2 common/conventions.rst common/app_support.rst common/glossary.rst Search in this guide ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * :ref:`search`

commit_message:
Add reno for release-notes

Add renote to automatically generate release notes - the same way other
OpenStack projects do it.
For details see
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/078301.html

Change-Id: I9789c5e21d8594593fc5536562a01644c6d63eef

commit_message:
Add specs directory to Kuryr

As the Kuryr community is increasing, a more
structured approach towards blueprints will be
very helpful. So added the specs directoty with
a skeleton and a template.

Change-Id: I8d1ee2c2d76a0d1b82eb5dd5963b33bfb31f5b9d

commit_message:
Few improvements in the quickstart doc

Fixed commands for disabling\stoping libvirt and ntpd in different OS

I encourage to install kolla tools via pip, so user could get rid
of relative paths to config and scripts and run it from everythere.

Change-Id: I77271ce2f72fbaa7d6586a84f7998a9888d9b3a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/67/242467/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pip install kolla/ cp -rp kolla/etc/kolla /etc/ yum downgrade docker-engine-1.8.2 systemctl restart docker.service sudo apt-get install -y python-dev python-pip libffi-dev libssl-dev gcc yum install -y python-devel libffi-devel openssl-devel gcc systemctl enable ntpd.service systemctl start ntpd.service # Centos 7 systemctl stop libvirtd.service systemctl disable libvirtd.service # Ubuntu service libvirt-bin stop update-rc.d libvirt-bin disableSome ansible dependencies, like pycrypto, may need gcc installed on the build system. Install it using system packaging tools if it's not installed already: :: # Centos 7 yum -y install gcc # Ubuntu sudo apt-get install gcc kolla-build kolla-build glance kolla-build -hAll variables for the environment can be specified in the files: kolla-ansible deploy kolla-ansible -h kolla/tools/init-runonce
deleted_lines: cd kolla sudo pip install -r requirements.txt yum downgrade docker-engine-1.8.2-1 service docker-engine restart sudo apt-get install -y python-dev python-pip libffi-dev libssl-dev yum install -y python-devel libffi-devel openssl-devel systemctl enable ntpd systemctl start ntpd service libvirtd disable service libvirtd stop tools/build.py tools/build.py glance tools/build.py -hCopy the etc/kolla directory from the git to /etc/kolla on the deployment host. All variables for the environment can be specified in the files: tools/kolla-ansible deploy tools/kolla-ansible -h tools/init-runonce

commit_message:
Update register_opts hacking check to allow tuples

Update the hacking check for register_opts to allow tuples to be
passed in directly as an argument. Previously tuples were getting
flagged as invalid due to a missing pair of parenthesis in the
hacking check.

commit_message:
remove default=None for config options

In the config module default=None is set as the default value,
it isn't necessary to set it again when doing config options.

Change-Id: Id6bbdb3c6b23bcc31d7a02057a73729e89cabb5c
Closes-Bug: #1323975

commit_message:
Return to publish-subscribe for etcd driver

On exception in the etcd client read, we perform a full sync process
this also happen every X time depending on the client read timeout.
This will help recover cases of exception in etcd publish-subscribe
notification and we can also lower the read timeout to achieve backup
sync cycle every X seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1507553

Change-Id: I2d295befa385405e70a1b602fbbfa132bca7c325

commit_message:
Only log router data when created

This patch will supress the constant log writing of router updates.
only on router creation or router interface modification
the controller will log the data.

Change-Id: Ic908a88d321c6cf6ff163cccf81b1c0135ffd7f6

commit_message:
Support correct lswitch update/add

When logical switch is read, compare to current value and only
change the object if any field changed, this reduce the number of
log printings to the screen

Change-Id: I0214a49ab44428a61da6317038f89ee4dbbd3a6c

commit_message:
Fix argument order for assertEqual to (expected, observed)

assertEqual expects that the arguments provided to it should be
(expected, observed).If a particluar order is kept as a convention,
then it helps to provide a cleaner message to the developer if Unit Tests
fail. There are several Unit Test files where the arguments for assertEqual
have been swapped. This commit fixes the issue in networking-midonet.

Change-Id: I00daee7e5628151e38d8becdfa7057c78aa48abe
Closes-Bug: #1259292

subject: Prevent DBError caused by wrong param passed to get_security_group
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-07 01:24:05.000000000', 'files': ['networking_ovn/plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/7700340b4b8e6c39e26982cf90813726ed731efe', 'message': "Prevent DBError caused by wrong param passed to get_security_group

Previously, in update_port() we would call _get_port() to get a copy
of the original port before we actually updated it. This original_port
value is in the form of a sqlalchemy object though and the method
update_security_group_on_port() uses the original port value to populate
update_port['security_groups'] I suppose to be helpful to the caller. In
our case, we'd later pass this value to get_security_groups and it would
give us an error of: DBError because we were passing a
neutron.db.securitygroups_db.SecurityGroupPortBinding rather than an id.

Change-Id: I04c522f6aed112dd3345f99ac80d582e667bab80
Closes-bug: #1514011
"}]
commit_message:
Prevent DBError caused by wrong param passed to get_security_group

Previously, in update_port() we would call _get_port() to get a copy
of the original port before we actually updated it. This original_port
value is in the form of a sqlalchemy object though and the method
update_security_group_on_port() uses the original port value to populate
update_port['security_groups'] I suppose to be helpful to the caller. In
our case, we'd later pass this value to get_security_groups and it would
give us an error of: DBError because we were passing a
neutron.db.securitygroups_db.SecurityGroupPortBinding rather than an id.

Change-Id: I04c522f6aed112dd3345f99ac80d582e667bab80
Closes-bug: #1514011

commit_message:
Add support for allowable network drivers configuration

Problem:
With the changes that were merged with https://review.openstack.org/230147, the
choices of container network drivers that can be selected for a given COE type
when creating a Magnum baymodel are hardcoded, and are based on network drivers
that Magnum can support for each COE.

These hard-coded selections will probably make sense in most cases. However, in
some cloud instances, a cloud provider or cloud admin may want to restrict the
choices of network drivers that a user can select for a given COE even further,
based on specific restrictions in the cloud.

Magnum should provide support for configuration of what container network
drivers are allowed, and this needs to be provided on a per-COE basis.

Proposed fix:
Add 3 configuration list options to the config in /etc/magnum/magnum.conf for
configuring allowed nework drivers for kubernetes, swarm and mesos
respectively. The keyword 'all' can be used to allow all network drivers
supported by Magnum for that COE. The new config options are:
- kubernetes_allowed_network_drivers
  (default=['all'])
- swarm_allowed_network_drivers
  (default=['all'])
- mesos_allowed_network_drivers
  (default=['all'])
Validation of the --network-driver attributes for a baymodel create will be
performed against this above configuration on a per-COE basis.

Change-Id: Ibaa21d43fd6b5c1a6acc10e56145280eeaea8534
Closes-Bug: #1504635

added_lines: def _test_create_baymodel_network_driver_attr(self, baymodel_dict, baymodel_config_dict, expect_errors, mock_keypair_exists, mock_image_data): for k, v in baymodel_config_dict.items(): cfg.CONF.set_override(k, v, 'baymodel') with mock.patch.object(self.dbapi, 'create_baymodel', wraps=self.dbapi.create_baymodel) as cc_mock: bdict = apiutils.baymodel_post_data(**baymodel_dict) response = self.post_json('/baymodels', bdict, expect_errors=expect_errors) if expect_errors: self.assertEqual(400, response.status_int) else: self.assertEqual(bdict['network_driver'], response.json['network_driver']) self.assertEqual(bdict['image_id'], response.json['image_id']) cc_mock.assert_called_once_with(mock.ANY) self.assertNotIn('id', cc_mock.call_args[0][0]) self.assertTrue(utils.is_uuid_like(response.json['uuid'])) def test_create_baymodel_with_network_driver(self): baymodel_dict = {'coe': 'kubernetes', 'network_driver': 'flannel'} config_dict = {} # Default config expect_errors_flag = False self._test_create_baymodel_network_driver_attr(baymodel_dict, config_dict, expect_errors_flag) def test_create_baymodel_with_no_network_driver(self): baymodel_dict = {} config_dict = {} expect_errors_flag = False self._test_create_baymodel_network_driver_attr(baymodel_dict, config_dict, expect_errors_flag) def test_create_baymodel_with_network_driver_non_def_config(self): baymodel_dict = {'coe': 'kubernetes', 'network_driver': 'flannel'} config_dict = { 'kubernetes_allowed_network_drivers': ['flannel', 'foo']} expect_errors_flag = False self._test_create_baymodel_network_driver_attr(baymodel_dict, config_dict, expect_errors_flag) def test_create_baymodel_with_invalid_network_driver(self): baymodel_dict = {'coe': 'kubernetes', 'network_driver': 'bad_driver'} config_dict = { 'kubernetes_allowed_network_drivers': ['flannel', 'good_driver']} expect_errors_flag = True self._test_create_baymodel_network_driver_attr(baymodel_dict, config_dict, expect_errors_flag)

Class method 'setUpClass' is executed for each test of test suite that

commit_message:
Fix usage of setUpClass method in functional tests

Class method 'setUpClass' is executed for each test of test suite that
appeared in new thread. It leads to creation of redundant resources,
and, hence, waste of resources.

So, add 'group_regex' option in testr config that will make all tests
of each class run in one thread.

Change-Id: I8100a98961791cee52b0866c7d593cc8371b3329
Closes-Bug: #1509460
(cherry picked from commit 7962533b94ae4abf48b3bdbc65564e7c1d6e6c7f)

commit_message:
Make string representation of DictModel generic

The previous version was specific to a port dict and would
fail if str() was called on other models. This iterates over
and logs all values of the dict instead so it works under any
dictionary.

Change-Id: I630b39338e4e67080e100a9f32c9b6e341a93472
Closes-Bug: #1512753
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/49/241249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pairs = ['%s=%s' % (k, v) for k, v in self.items()] return ', '.join(sorted(pairs))

commit_message:
DNM: more debug logging for cells BDM race failure

We need more logging to know when we're creating BDMs, where we're
coming from when we hit the parent cell to update or create, and
if we're able to detect duplicates based on bdm source id (snapshot_id)
when the device_name isn't set.

Change-Id: I9378ee252ab4a19ed598a7e69df42db9d8c8153c
Related-Bug: #1489581
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/17/242517/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_bdm_source_id(bdm): """Return the volume_id, snapshot_id or image_id if set. :param bdm: block device mapping v2 dict :returns: volume_id, snapshot_id, image_id or None if not set """ for type in ('volume_id', 'snapshot_id', 'image_id'): if type in bdm and bdm[type]: return bdm[type] else: # have we nulled out the device_name b/c of the libvirt driver code # key off the volume/snapshot/image id if not a blank bdm bdm_source_id = _get_bdm_source_id(values) if bdm_source_id: bdms = self.block_device_mapping_get_all_by_instance( context, values['instance_uuid']) for bdm in bdms: existing_bdm_source_id = _get_bdm_source_id(bdm) if bdm_source_id == existing_bdm_source_id: LOG.warning('Multiple BDMs found with the same source ' 'ID %s but different device_names ' '(%s - %s).', bdm_source_id, values['device_name'], bdm.get('device_name'), instance_uuid=values['instance_uuid'])

commit_message:
Remove manager-driver assignment metadata construct

The old kvs-inspired metadata construct was still hanging around
between the assignment manager and driver. This patch removes this
and re-uses other existing methods in its place.

Implements: blueprint remove-role-metadata

Change-Id: Ic7737fc44c1d1a86521c428216316d06b67dd1f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/95/148995/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _assert_not_domain_grant(self, domain_id): if domain_id is not None: msg = _('Domain grants not supported by LDAP') raise exception.NotImplemented(message=msg) self._assert_not_domain_grant(domain_id) self._add_role_to_group_and_project( self.add_role_to_user_and_project( self._assert_not_domain_grant(domain_id)
deleted_lines: def _get_metadata(self, user_id=None, tenant_id=None, domain_id=None, group_id=None): def _get_roles_for_just_user_and_project(user_id, tenant_id): user_dn = self.user._id_to_dn(user_id) return [self.role._dn_to_id(a.role_dn) for a in self.role.get_role_assignments (self.project._id_to_dn(tenant_id)) if common_ldap.is_dn_equal(a.user_dn, user_dn)] def _get_roles_for_group_and_project(group_id, project_id): group_dn = self.group._id_to_dn(group_id) return [self.role._dn_to_id(a.role_dn) for a in self.role.get_role_assignments (self.project._id_to_dn(project_id)) if common_ldap.is_dn_equal(a.user_dn, group_dn)] if domain_id is not None: msg = _('Domain metadata not supported by LDAP') raise exception.NotImplemented(message=msg) if group_id is None and user_id is None: return {} if tenant_id is None: return {} if user_id is None: metadata_ref = _get_roles_for_group_and_project(group_id, tenant_id) else: metadata_ref = _get_roles_for_just_user_and_project(user_id, tenant_id) if not metadata_ref: return {} return {'roles': [self._role_to_dict(r, False) for r in metadata_ref]} try: metadata_ref = self._get_metadata(user_id, project_id, domain_id, group_id) except exception.MetadataNotFound: metadata_ref = {} metadata_ref['roles'] = self._add_role_to_group_and_project( metadata_ref['roles'] = self.add_role_to_user_and_project( try: metadata_ref = self._get_metadata(user_id, project_id, domain_id, group_id) except exception.MetadataNotFound: metadata_ref = {}

Update minimum tox version to 1.8

Other projects have updated to 1.8 or later for the minimum
tox version (nova, neutron), so we should probably do the
same.

Change-Id: Iddb9ab286519d555671ec39c0ce75c9351025730

commit_message:
Brocade driver add_zone optimization

Check whether the new zone we want to add/create
has the same zone name and members with the existing
zone on the switch. If they are same, no need to
delete and re-add it. This is significant if we
create volume from image or upload volume to image
in batch.

Implements: blueprint brocade-add-zone-optimization
Change-Id: I257ec25fed9fab4b3a85a0f200c2ee426c8e6f8c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/04/234004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _is_zone_same(self, zone1, zone2): zone_members1 = ';'.join(str(member) for member in zone1) zone_members2 = ';'.join(str(member) for member in zone1) if zone_members1 == zone_members2: return True else: return False if self._is_zone_same(zones[zone], zone_list[zone]): break if not zone_with_sep: return

commit_message:
Delete the API guide

The API guide points to the "quick start" guide, so we can delete
the API guide in the api-site repository.

Change-Id: I61b8ed90afb05e7309abd601af6c5024ab8865e3
Closes-Bug: #1514021

commit_message:
Add module_path column to datasource table

Only datasource_manager has a map between a datasource driver and
a path of the datasource class. Datasource_manager will be deleted
in the distributed architecture, so it enables API model classes to
get the map from congress DB.

Change-Id: I4d16e4b32a4aaf2916c65d70fd0bf07e82eefc79
Partially-Implements: blueprint dist-api-rpcify-schema

commit_message:
config reference for neutron (networking-zvm)

  As a workaround, networking-zvm can generate config reference
  by directory copying to neutron tree in source directory.
  
  This patch will be reverted after name space fixation
  in networking-zvm.

  currently name space header uses "neutron",
  This causes conflict with neutron itself.

Change-Id: Ia86eabf8c982431dbf6af727373349d3c2add1a9
Related-Bug: #1503967

commit_message:
Add protocol to help of glance_api_servers option

Help for glance_api_servers option lacked information that it is
possible to specify protocol there (http or https) and suggested that
it isn't possible to use HTTPS in connection from Cinder to Glance.
This commit expands the message to include such information.

Change-Id: I5afa33193b6dda2477e5a28fa042e625d449257b
Closes-Bug: 1509065
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/78/238678/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help='A list of the URLs of glance API servers available to ' 'cinder ([http[s]://][hostname|ip]:port). If protocol ' 'is not specified it defaults to http.'),
deleted_lines: help='A list of the glance API servers available to cinder ' '([hostname|ip]:port)'),

commit_message:
Fix log message formatting that cause log errors

Log messages take *args for the format replacements instead of a
tuple.  This fixes the 2 that were using tuples.

Closes-Bug: #1513302
Change-Id: Idb3927427684d8a2e053543f76a5085a15753007

commit_message:
Pool-aware Scheduler Support

For migrating volumes, the user needs to provide pool
and backend-name information as part of the host string.

Change-Id: I35091899cf8828df7a44fc1b43d4ef8b7f896fea
Closes-bug: #1363830
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/84/242584/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Destination host. Takes the form 'host@backend-name#pool'. Destination host. Takes the form 'host@backend-nama#pool'.

commit_message:
Swap out pyOpenSSL for cryptography in LocalCertGenerator

In certain cases (non-deterministic? maybe OS related?) the pyOpenSSL
bindings were not working properly, and since I was meaning to do
this eventually anyway, I just went ahead and did it now.

Change-Id: Ifb71f507875eef5f540eb602c3328b0f563b9796

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/242428/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _scale(self, req, instance_id, delta_vcpus, delta_memory, **kwargs): """Start scale-insatnce operation with given vcpus/memory deltas.""" context = req.environ["nova.context"] instance = self._get_server(context, req, instance_id) try: self.compute_api.scale(context, instance, delta_vcpus, delta_memory, **kwargs) except exception.QuotaError as error: raise exc.HTTPForbidden( explanation=error.format_message(), headers={'Retry-After': 0}) except exception.InstanceIsLocked as e: raise exc.HTTPConflict(explanation=e.format_message()) except exception.InstanceInvalidState as state_error: common.raise_http_conflict_for_instance_invalid_state(state_error, 'scale', instance_id) return webob.Response(status_int=202) @wsgi.action('scale') def _action_scale(self, req, id, body): """Scale a given instance with sepcified vcpus/memory deltas. Sign of delta quantities indicate direction of scale. Deltas with positive sign indicate scale-up and deltas with negative sign indicate scale-down. """ try: delta_vcpus = int(body["scale"]["delta_vcpus"]) delta_memory = int(body["scale"]["delta_memory"]) if not delta_vcpus and not delta_memory: msg = _("scale request has invalid delta_vcpus and " "delta_memory attributes.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) except (KeyError, TypeError): msg = _("scale requests require delta_vcpus or " "delta_memory attributes.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) return self._scale(req, id, delta_vcpus, delta_memory) @wsgi.response(202) @wsgi.serializers(xml=FullServerTemplate) @wsgi.deserializers(xml=ActionDeserializer)

It was discovered that the Python imp.find_module() method behaves
differently on Mac environments. Sometimes it does not find the
specified module even if it does exist on the sys.path.

To fix this for all platforms, the code was refactored to use the

commit_message:
Refactor dynamic types mapping feature to use importlib

It was discovered that the Python imp.find_module() method behaves
differently on Mac environments. Sometimes it does not find the
specified module even if it does exist on the sys.path.

To fix this for all platforms, the code was refactored to use the
importlib.import_module() method. This module looks to correctly
work on both platforms, Linux and Mac OSX.

Change-Id: I521cd430dc04f60e44c192cb3194a0ae07efacb7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator refs/changes/68/231168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import importlib mod_name = mod_name.replace('/', '.') try: mod = importlib.import_module(mod_name)
deleted_lines: import imp _load_custom_mod(custom_path)def _load_custom_mod(custom_path): '''Dynamically load the parent module for all the custom types.''' fp = None try: fp, filename, desc = imp.find_module(custom_path) imp.load_module(custom_path.replace('/', '.'), fp, filename, desc) except ImportError: raise ToscaModImportError(mod_name=custom_path) finally: if fp: fp.close() try: fp, filename, desc = imp.find_module(mod_name) mod = imp.load_module(mod_name.replace('/', '.'), fp, filename, desc) finally: fp.close()

subject: Set SERVICE_HOST, enable cache, install key, tempest and monasca only
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-07 19:34:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api/commit/b0d5c72369b46e5d336d27b0832f7f4491825d6b', 'message': 'Set SERVICE_HOST, enable cache, install key, tempest and monasca only

Set SERVICE_HOT=192.168.10.6. When OpenStack services register with
Keystone, they will register using the IP address that is accessible
to the host OS.

Enable the vagrant-cachier to speed-up subsequent deploys.

Diable all OpenStack services except for mysql, rabbit, key and
monasca. This will reduce the size of the VM and speed-up

commit_message:
Set SERVICE_HOST, enable cache, install key, tempest and monasca only

Set SERVICE_HOT=192.168.10.6. When OpenStack services register with
Keystone, this will register using the IP address that is accessible
from the host OS.

Enable the vagrant-cachier to speed-up subsequent deploys.

Disable all OpenStack services except for mysql, rabbit, key and
monasca. This will reduce the size of the VM and speed-up
deploys.

Change-Id: I791cce4dbf3a7f1c2297fb288886aae35ada4658

added_lines: def _scale(self, req, instance_id, delta_vcpus, delta_memory, **kwargs): """Start scale-insatnce operation with given vcpus/memory deltas.""" context = req.environ["nova.context"] instance = self._get_server(context, req, instance_id) try: self.compute_api.scale(context, instance, delta_vcpus, delta_memory, **kwargs) except exception.QuotaError as error: raise exc.HTTPForbidden( explanation=error.format_message(), headers={'Retry-After': 0}) except exception.InstanceIsLocked as e: raise exc.HTTPConflict(explanation=e.format_message()) except exception.InstanceInvalidState as state_error: common.raise_http_conflict_for_instance_invalid_state(state_error, 'scale', instance_id) return webob.Response(status_int=202) @wsgi.action('scale') def _action_scale(self, req, id, body): """Scale a given instance with sepcified vcpus/memory deltas. Sign of delta quantities indicate direction of scale. Deltas with positive sign indicate scale-up and deltas with negative sign indicate scale-down. """ try: delta_vcpus = int(body["scale"]["delta_vcpus"]) delta_memory = int(body["scale"]["delta_memory"]) if not delta_vcpus and not delta_memory: msg = _("scale request has invalid delta_vcpus and " "delta_memory attributes.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) except (KeyError, TypeError): msg = _("scale requests require delta_vcpus or " "delta_memory attributes.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) return self._scale(req, id, delta_vcpus, delta_memory) @wsgi.response(202) @wsgi.serializers(xml=FullServerTemplate) @wsgi.deserializers(xml=ActionDeserializer)

commit_message:
Deprecate local conductor mode

Way back when we started no-db-compute, we introduced the conductor service
and provided a "local mode" which made conductor's API layer a passthrough to
the manager and thus the database. This eliminated the need to move to
conductor for deployments that weren't ready or had other blockers.

Now, conductor is a pretty critical part of nova's infrastructure and
continuing to allow both modes invites issues (such as bug 1505471). This
patch starts the timer on deprecation for this mode of operation so that
we can remove it in the future.

UpgradeImpact: A deployment mode is being deprecated and will require any
existing operators using this to deploy conductor before removal.

Change-Id: Ifbd5578dcc53b2117674db2016e5d882a82866aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/242168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Replace python-keystoneclient with OSC

OpenStackClient is recommended to interact with
Keystone instead of python-keystoneclient now.
This patch replaces python-keystoneclient with
OpenStackClient.

Change-Id: I26e2c13a185fbe2aa993eb31bbeb4cad96f9bddb

commit_message:
[spec] Improve and make pluggable type conversion

This proposes to make resource type converters into proper plugins,
stop depending on OpenStack as much as is possible without modifying
validation, and make some improvements to handle an edge case
converting images.

Change-Id: If078332230df417b3967f086815796c7a96fa882
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/75/237175/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============== Pluggable Types =============== Rally's current type resolution subsystem (``rally.common.types``) isn't easily pluggable, is tied to OpenStack, and cannot handle resources that must be resolved by the context of each iteration rather than the context of the subtask. This spec aims to solve all three problems. Problem description =================== The Rally ``types.set()`` decorator is used to convert resource names or regular expressions to resource objects. For instance, in a task file a user can specify: .. code-block:: yaml image: regex: cirros-.*-uec flavor: name: m1.tiny Rally will convert those into the matching image ID and flavor ID. As it currently exists, this process has several shortcomings and bugs: * Although it is technically pluggable, the resource type classes do not call ``rally.common.plugin.configure`` and the code is not patterned as a plugin, with code in ``rally.plugins``. Technically, a user could implement a subclass of ``rally.common.types.ResourceType`` in a plugin and use it, but this is not obvious from the code or documentation, and it would not be registered as a plugin. Moreover, OpenStack-specific resources are in the ``rally.common.types`` module instead of the OpenStack plugin. * It is tied to OpenStack. ``rally.common.types.preprocess()`` loads an OpenStack Clients object and passes it to the resource type objects. * In some cases, resources must be loaded by the client context created for each iteration, not by the admin context. For instance, when Glance images are created by the ``images`` context they are created as private images in each tenant; trying to load the image with the admin context fails. We need to be able to support this use case, without taking on a significant or universal performance penalty. Proposed change =============== The arguments with which each preprocessor is called will be changed. Instead of: .. code-block:: python def transform(cls, clients, resource_config): ...it will be: .. code-block:: python def transform(cls, resource_config, context=None, clients=None): Within the types subsystem proper, only ``context`` will be passed; ``clients`` will remain for compatibility with the validation subsystem, which does not have a context object yet, and remains tied to OpenStack. If ``clients`` is not passed to ``transform()``, the responsibility for creating OpenStack clients (or doing anything else with the subtask context) will lie with the ``ResourceType`` subclass itself. This entails a small performance penalty, but it's necessary to divorce the types subsystem from OpenStack. If ``clients`` is passed, then a deprecation warning will be logged. When the validation subsystem is made independent from OpenStack, the ``clients`` keyword argument should be removed. Second, ``ResourceType.transform()`` will no longer be a class method. As a result, ``types.set()`` will need to accept objects instead of classes; i.e., this: .. code-block:: python @types.set(image=types.ImageResourceType, flavor=types.FlavorResourceType) ...will change to: .. code-block:: python @types.set(image=types.ImageResourceType(), flavor=types.FlavorResourceType()) This will allow the resource classes to retain persistent information about a single decorated scenario function. ``transform`` will also be renamed to ``preprocess``, which will be more consistent with ``rally.common.types.preprocess`` and will make it easier to add a second resource type resolution hook, described below. Third, a new hook will be added to the runners. In addition to ``types.preprocess()``, which is run after contexts but before the scenarios start, ``types.preiteration()`` will run before each iteration of the scenario. Together with the change to make ``types.set()`` accept objects instead of classes, this will solve the issue of resources that must be resolved per-iteration. For instance, to resolve images, ``ImageResourceType.preprocess()`` would resolve images for each set of credentials created for the subtask, as well as for the admin credentials, and cache them; ``ImageResourceType.preiteration()`` would be passed the mapped scenario context and the resource configuration, and would choose the correct image ID to pass to the scenario. Note that image listing and resolution is not done by ``preiteration()``; we should strive to keep the performance profile of ``preiteration()`` as small as possible. In order to simplify the type resolution workflow, only ``preiteration()`` will be able to rewrite arguments, but the default implementation in ``rally.common.types.ResourceType`` will rewrite it with the value cached in ``preprocess()``. For instance: .. code-block:: python class ResourceType(object): @abc.abstractmethod def preprocess(self, context, resource_config): pass def preiteration(self, context, resource_config): return self.value class FlavorResourceType(ResourceType): def preprocess(self, context, resource_config): self.value = resource_config.get("id") if not self.value: novaclient = clients.nova() self.value = _id_from_name(resource_config=resource_config, resources=novaclient.flavors.list(), typename="flavor") This does lead to some redundancy -- flavor arguments will be rewritten on each iteration, for instance -- but as it's only a matter of changing a few values in the argument dict, the performance penalty will be minimal. Finally, the code will be rearranged to make it obviously pluggable, and a ``types.configure()`` call will be added to register the ``ResourceType`` subclasses as plugins. OpenStack resources will be moved into the OpenStack plugin space, and documentation will be added to make it clear that ``ResourceType`` can be subclassed by other plugins. This is done last since the types interfaces will be in substantial flux as the rest of this spec is implemented, and we don't want to make those changing interfaces any more public than necessary until they are more stable. Alternatives ------------ Type resolution could be done in a single step (as opposed to the two step ``preprocess()``/``preiteration()``) if we passed the results in the context object instead of rewriting scenario arguments. This is less straightforward, though; the scenario author would then need to know where to look in the context to find the resource object, even though for any given iteration there is exactly one resource object that is appropriate. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stpierre aka Chris St. Pierre Work Items ---------- * Change arguments to ``ResourceType.transform()`` to accept the context, not OpenStack clients, and offload OpenStack client creation to the ``ResourceType`` subclasses. (This should be done in a new abstract intermediate subclass, ``OpenStackResourceType``.) * Rename ``ResourceType.transform()`` and make it an instance method. * Add the ``ResourceType.preiteration()`` hook. * Rewrite any resource types that need to take advantage of the new ``preiteration()`` hook. This will likely be limited to ``ImageResourceType`` and ``EC2ImageResourceType``. If there are obvious patterns that can be abstracted out, then add a new abstract intermediate subclass. * Rearrange the code into plugins and add plugin documentation. Dependencies ============ None.

commit_message:
Move update_fip_statuses to Router class

I noticed that ri.floating_ips was being accessed from the agent.  It
didn't seem right.  Also, noticed that this set gets passed around too
much between methods.  It all boils down to saving the previous set
and then doing set difference to see which ones went away.  This patch
set makes it simpler.

Partially-Implements: blueprint address-scopes

Change-Id: I73424620e196200c70f221871c34e33ccfe73261
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/04/231204/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.update_fip_statuses(agent, fip_statuses) def update_fip_statuses(self, agent, fip_statuses): # Identify floating IPs which were disabled existing_floating_ips = self.floating_ips self.floating_ips = set(fip_statuses.keys()) for fip_id in existing_floating_ips - self.floating_ips: fip_statuses[fip_id] = l3_constants.FLOATINGIP_STATUS_DOWN # filter out statuses that didn't change fip_statuses = {f: stat for f, stat in fip_statuses.items() if stat != FLOATINGIP_STATUS_NOCHANGE} if not fip_statuses: return LOG.debug('Sending floating ip statuses: %s', fip_statuses) # Update floating IP status on the neutron server agent.plugin_rpc.update_floatingip_statuses( agent.context, self.router_id, fip_statuses)
deleted_lines: existing_floating_ips = self.floating_ips agent.update_fip_statuses( self, existing_floating_ips, fip_statuses)

commit_message:
Make '*' the default ml2 flat_networks configuration

Update the ml2 flat_networks configuration to set '*' as the
default because that has been effectively the default behavior due
to a bug with the empty list.

Also, fix the empty list configuration for disabling flat networks.

DocImpact
UpgradeImpact

Change-Id: I13eb22afd7c0d011154b58a1bd218fd4fa82a8d9
Closes-bug: #1437745
Co-Authored-By: Martin Hickey <martin.hickey@ie.ibm.com>

subject: [WIP] Deploy multinode in gate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-04 07:12:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/242aae4bce50c1a222e7be384f412657fca52765', 'message': '[WIP] Deploy multinode in gate

This is very rough but gets the basic idea across for multinode in a
single node. Some points for reflection:

* sysctl breaks in the container due to missing /proc entries for some
  modules (in this case the bridge module)
* --pid=host launches the process in the same pid namespace as the
  docker daemon resides in, not the true host pid namespace
* The only way the containers can communicate is via L2 over a bridge
  on the host. This means packets must leave OVS module and traverse
  the kernel network stack (multinode from L2 perspective)
* BTRFS is saving the day here by skipping the registry push/pull

  docker daemon resides in, not the true host pid namespace
* The only way the containers can communicate is via L2 over a bridge
  on the host. This means packets must leave OVS module and traverse
  the kernel network stack (multinode from L2 perspective)
* BTRFS is saving the day here by skipping the registry push/pull

Change-Id: I0fcaac2e0cf5634aacd19c3b615ff5216b54160f
Partially-Implements: blueprint multinode-gate
'}]
commit_message:
[WIP] Deploy multinode in gate

This is very rough but gets the basic idea across for multinode in a
single node. Some points for reflection:

* sysctl breaks in the container due to missing /proc entries for some
  modules (in this case the bridge module)
* --pid=host launches the process in the same pid namespace as the
  docker daemon resides in, not the true host pid namespace
* The only way the containers can communicate is via L2 over a bridge
  on the host. This means packets must leave OVS module and traverse
  the kernel network stack (multinode from L2 perspective)
* BTRFS is saving the day here by skipping the registry push/pull

Change-Id: I0fcaac2e0cf5634aacd19c3b615ff5216b54160f
Partially-Implements: blueprint multinode-gate

commit_message:
Implement default host maintenance mode handling.

This patch implements a default host_maintenance_mode in compute.
It calls driver's corresponding API. If the driver has not implemented
one, it falls back to the default one.

The reason why doing this is: host maintenance mode handling could
be handled in compute and conductor. It doesn't have to fall into
driver level. Of cource, a driver could provide its own handling
using its special functionaries, e.g. Xen.

Change-Id: I4615d3965d992348afe91822e6f84c168d465dc2
Implements: blueprint host-maintenance-mode
Signed-off-by: Tang Chen <tangchen@cn.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/40/233540/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :param mode: This bool value specifies whether the host will be put into maintenance mode. True if yes, False if no.

commit_message:
Add host_maintenance_mode() API to conductor.

This patch implements a host_maintenance_mode() in conductor.
It migrates all instances on the compute node, and run into
monitor waiting for all migrations finish.

The call trace looks like this:

nova-api
|-> compute-api: host_maintenance_mode()
    |-> compute-rpcapi: host_maintenance_mode()
        |-> compute-manager: host_maintenance_mode()
            |-> Libvirt driver: host_maintenance_mode() ---- Not implemented.
|-----------|
|           |-> Set host to maintenance mode.
|               (Waiting until migration monitor returns.)
V
conductor-api: host_maintenance_mode()
|-> conductor-rpcapi: host_maintenance_mode()
    |-> conductor-manager: host_maintenance_mode()
        |-> conductor-manager: migration_monitor()
        |   (Return when migration finishes.)
        |-> conductor-manager: migrate_server()
            |-> conductor-manager: _live_migrate()
                |-> task: _execute()
                    |-> task: _find_destination()
|-------------------|
V
compute-rpcapi: live_migration()
|-> compute-manager: live_migration()
    |-> compute-manager: live_migration().
        |-> thread: _do_live_migration()
            |-> libvirt driver: live_migration()
                |-> libvirt driver: _live_migration()
                    |-> thread: _live_migration_operation()
                    |-> libvirt driver: _live_migration_monitor()

Unit tests will be added in the next version if the implementation is OK.

Change-Id: I06707ebc8d437137952a7a7188f07e69a323f491
Implements: blueprint host-maintenance-mode
Signed-off-by: Tang Chen <tangchen@cn.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/39/233539/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.compute import flavors from nova.compute import power_state def host_maintenance_mode(self, context, instances, host, mode): if not instances or not mode: return True # The host is going to be set to maintenance mode, so we should not # migrate instances to itself. filter_properties = {'ignore_hosts': [host]} scheduler_hint = {'host': None, 'filter_properties': filter_properties} migrations = [] for instance in instances: instance.tase_state = task_states.MIGRATING instance.save(expected_task_state=[None]) migration = objects.Migration(context=context.elevated()) migrations.append(migration) # According to migrate_server(), all the other migrations have not # been implemented except the two below. if instance.power_state not in (power_state.RUNNING, power_state.PAUSED): # For code migration. live = False flavor = flavors.get_flavor(1) else: # For live migration. live = True flavor = None # Call migrate_server() without target host. The live migration # task will choose an appropriate host for each instance. self.migrate_server(context, instance, scheduler_hint, live=live, rebuild=False, flavor=flavor, block_migration=False, disk_over_commit=False, migration=migration) # This function should be synchronized. We should ensure that all the # instances have been migrated successfully. Otherwise we cannot # disable compute service. if self._live_migration_monitor(context, migrations): return True return False

commit_message:
Define Migration object in migrate_server() in conductor.

In the current code, Migration object is defined in _live_migrate().
But according to the previous patch, we need to pass Migration
objects to live migration monitor to check if the migrations are
successful in the end. So we make it a parameter of _live_migrate().
If not passed, we define one in _live_migration().

Unit tests will be added in the next version if this implementation is OK.

Change-Id: I2cd18b54833787d0b765969e2caccd5e2ddb4bea
Implements: blueprint host-maintenance-mode
Signed-off-by: Tang Chen <tangchen@cn.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
Implement a migration monitor in conductor.

Host maintenance mode means:
1. Disable compute service on the compute node.
2. Migrate all instances to other compute nodes.
3. Maintain the node (hardware or system upgrade).
4. Reenable compute service on the node.

If migrations fail, we should not set the host to maintenance mode
because the instances are still running on the host. So we need a
monitor to get the result of migrations.

This patch implements a simple migration monitor in conductor. It
takes a list of instances in migration status, checks their
migration_statuses every 1 section. If any of the migration failed,
the monitor returns False, and the caller decides what to do next.

PS: There are some problems in current usage of migration status.
    I have tried to fix them, but the BP won't be approved.
    (https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-migration-statuses)
    Will fix them in another way soon.

Change-Id: I903ace5b4a674f28b77e193a1554a8c9dc109643
Implements: blueprint host-maintenance-mode
Signed-off-by: Tang Chen <tangchen@cn.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/233537/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time def _live_migration_monitor(self, context, migrations): """Monitor the statuses of multiple live migrations. This monitor will make conductor be able to know if migrations succeeded or failed on compute nodes, while keeping migration process asynchronized. Return True if all instances have been migrated successfully, False otherwise. """ total = len(migrations) migrated = 0 while len(migrations): for migration in migrations: status = migration.status if status in ('failed', 'error'): # If migration fails, remove it from the list. migrations.remove(migration) elif status in ('finished', 'completed', 'done'): # If migration succeeds, count it and remove it. migrated += 1 migrations.remove(migration) # True if all instances have been migrated successfully. time.sleep(1) return migrated == total

commit_message:
Enable host maintenance mode in libvirt driver.

This patch implements host_maintenance_mode() API in Libvirt driver.

In Libvirt driver, it enables/disables nova-compute service. And the real
call to realize_host_maintenance() API is implemented in host.py.

Change-Id: Iabefc8fd52887efe6bd5c2c0284bbbdd27ff82fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/42/194542/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import compute self._host_api = compute.HostAPI() def host_maintenance_mode(self, host, mode): """Start/Stop host maintenance window. On start, it triggers guest VMs evacuation. """ if not mode: return 'off_maintenance' ctxt = nova_context.get_admin_context() try: # Host maintenance handler uses synchronous live migration call # in conductor, so the remote exception will be caught and # re-raised locally by RPC. self._host_api.realize_host_maintenance(ctxt, host, mode) except: return 'off_maintenance' return 'on_maintenance'

subject: Enable synchronous live migration in libvirt driver.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-23 08:28:16.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/conductor/manager.py', 'nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py', 'nova/compute/rpcapi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/990aa2f3df7f0ad3c69c52b89ff4d55b9e02bd5c', 'message': 'Enable synchronous live migration in libvirt driver.

When putting host to maintenance mode, nova-compute service will be disabled
to prevent new instance created on this host. And then migrate all running
instances to other hosts. But the migration may fail. On failure, we have to
re-enable nova-compute service because we failed to put host to maintenance mode.

To do this, we must catch remote exception raised in migration flow. There are
two things need to do:
1. In compute-rpcapi, live_migration interface is called with cctxt.cast(), which
   is an asychronized method in oslo_messaging. It is unable to catch exceptions
   raised by remote hosts.
   To catch remote exception and re-raise it locally, we need to use cctxt.call().
2. In migration flow in Libvirt driver, the real work is done in a thread created
   with greenthread. We have to call greenthread.wait() to wait the thread finishes
   and catch exceptions raised in the thread.

If the above two things are done, the migration flow will become a synchronous call.
So this patch adds a new key:value pair "sync:True/False" to migrate_data parameter
in migration flow. It is used to control if the migration flow should be called
synchronously. Currently the only user of synchronous migration call is host
maintenance mode in Libvirt driver.

Change-Id: I392f97163d85569a09c2cb6d7eb1882e6bc806c2

commit_message:
Enable synchronous live migration in libvirt driver.

When putting host to maintenance mode, nova-compute service will be disabled
to prevent new instance created on this host. And then migrate all running
instances to other hosts. But the migration may fail. On failure, we have to
re-enable nova-compute service because we failed to put host to maintenance mode.

To do this, we must catch remote exception raised in migration flow. There are
two things need to do:
1. In compute-rpcapi, live_migration interface is called with cctxt.cast(), which
   is an asychronized method in oslo_messaging. It is unable to catch exceptions
   raised by remote hosts.
   To catch remote exception and re-raise it locally, we need to use cctxt.call().
2. In migration flow in Libvirt driver, the real work is done in a thread created
   with greenthread. We have to call greenthread.wait() to wait the thread finishes
   and catch exceptions raised in the thread.

If the above two things are done, the migration flow will become a synchronous call.
So this patch adds a new key:value pair "sync:True/False" to migrate_data parameter
in migration flow. It is used to control if the migration flow should be called
synchronously. Currently the only user of synchronous migration call is host
maintenance mode in Libvirt driver.

Change-Id: I392f97163d85569a09c2cb6d7eb1882e6bc806c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/194541/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (migrate_data is not None and migrate_data.has_key('sync') and migrate_data['sync']): cctxt.call(ctxt, 'live_migration', instance=instance, dest=dest, block_migration=block_migration, migrate_data=migrate_data) else: cctxt.cast(ctxt, 'live_migration', instance=instance, dest=dest, block_migration=block_migration, migrate_data=migrate_data)

commit_message:
Add realize_host_maintenance() API to compute.

According to the previous patch, host maintenance mode will work like this:
nova-api
|-> compute-api: host_maintenance_mode()
    |-> compute-rpcapi: host_maintenance_mode()
        |-> compute-manager: host_maintenance_mode()
            |-> Libvirt driver: host_maintenance_mode()
                                |
|-------------------------------|
V
compute-api: realize_host_maintenance()
|-> compute-rpcapi: realize_host_maintenance()
    |-> compute-manager: realize_host_maintenance()
        |-> conductor-api: realize_host_maintenance()
            |-> conductor-rpcapi: realize_host_maintenance()
                |-> conductor-manager: realize_host_maintenance()
                    |-> conductor-manager: migrate_server()

So this patch adds realize_host_maintenance() interface to nova-compute.

Change-Id: I1323d6afa73a5a2cf52449bbec557c918b22fa00

commit_message:
Add realize_host_maintenance() API to conductor.

This patch-set aims at implementing host maintenance mode in Libvirt driver.

When user inputs "nova host-update XXX --maintenance enable" command,
host maintenance mode works like this:
1. Disable nova-compute service in host XXX, so that nova-scheduler won't
   create new instance on that host.
2. Migrate all running instances to other hosts.
   (Ask nova-scheduler to pick up suitable hosts for the migration.)
3. Set the host to maintenance mode.

When user inputs "nova host-update XXX --maintenance disable" command,
host maintenance mode works like this:
1. Simply enable nova-compute service.

The command runs from nova-api level, through nova-compute, and then to the
Libvirt driver, like this:
nova-api
|-> compute-api
    |-> compute-rpcapi
        |-> compute-manage
            |-> Libvirt driver: host_maintenance_mode()

In order to call migration flow in nova-conductor, an interface needs to be
added to conductor. We name this interface as realize_host_maintenance().
It is going to be like this:
nova-api
|-> compute-api: host_maintenance_mode()
    |-> compute-rpcapi: host_maintenance_mode()
        |-> compute-manager: host_maintenance_mode()
            |-> Libvirt driver: host_maintenance_mode()
                                |
|-------------------------------|
V
compute-api: realize_host_maintenance()
|-> compute-rpcapi: realize_host_maintenance()
    |-> compute-manager: realize_host_maintenance()
        |-> conductor-api: realize_host_maintenance()
            |-> conductor-rpcapi: realize_host_maintenance()
                |-> conductor-manager: realize_host_maintenance()
                    |-> conductor-manager: migrate_server()

So this patch adds realize_host_maintenance() interface to nova-conductor.
It is the interface to call migration flow from host-update command.

Change-Id: Ic6da1e8592b5a084a527969e50eed8fadfa73649
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/39/194539/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfgCONF = cfg.CONF def realize_host_maintenance(self, context, instances, src_host): filter_properties = {'ignore_hosts': []} if src_host and not CONF.allow_resize_to_same_host: filter_properties['ignore_hosts'].append(src_host) scheduler_hint = {'host': None, 'filter_properties': filter_properties} for instance in instances: instance.tase_state = task_states.MIGRATING instance.save(expected_task_state=[None]) # Call migrate_server() without target host. The scheduler will # choose an appropriate host for each instance. self.migrate_server(context, instance, scheduler_hint, live=True, rebuild=False, flavor=None, block_migration=False, disk_over_commit=False)

commit_message:
Boot a vm on a shared public network by default

If there is a shared public network, tell nova to boot on it by default.
This works around the UI problem where if there is a public and a
private nova can't infer what you want to do. Also, allow specifying a
network by name and add a boolean to control the behavior. So that if
you want to boot private and you have a shared public network, it's as
easy as public=False, network=my-network-name.

Change-Id: I258d0a6330b8bce74e0db390a207ca307cef38da

commit_message:
Implements: Neutron netpartitions

Change-Id: I4ab958d2a5cc1aba36ab803a5fecc15899577b2d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/54/241254/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def search_netpartitions(self, name_or_id=None, filters=None): """Search OpenStack netpartitions :param name_or_id: Name or id of the desired netpartition. :param filters: a dict containing additional filters to use. :returns: a list of dicts containing the netpartition description. :raises: ``OpenStackCloudException`` if something goes wrong during the openstack API call. """ netpartitions = self.list_netpartitions(filters) return _utils._filter_list(netpartitions, name_or_id, filters) def list_netpartitions(self, filters=None): """List all available netpartitions. :param filters: (optional) dict of filter conditions to push down :returns: A list of subnet dicts. """ # Translate None from search interface to empty {} for kwargs below if not filters: filters = {} with self._neutron_exceptions("Error fetching netpartition list"): return self.manager.submitTask( _tasks.NetpartitionList(**filters))['net_partitions'] def get_netpartition(self, name_or_id, filters=None): """Get a netpartition by name or ID. :param name_or_id: Name or ID of the netpartition. :param dict filters: A dictionary of meta data to use for further filtering. Elements of this dictionary may, themselves, be dictionaries. Example:: { 'last_name': 'Smith', 'other': { 'gender': 'Female' } } :returns: A netpartition dict or None if no matching netpartition is found. """ return _utils._get_entity(self.search_netpartitions, name_or_id, filters) def create_netpartition(self, netpartition_name, netpartition_id=None): """Create a netpartiton. :param string netpartition_name: The unique name for the net partition. If a non-unique name is supplied, an exception is raised. :param string netpartition_id: The ID of the net partition. :returns: The new net partition object. :raises: OpenStackCloudException on operation error. """ # The body of the neutron message for the netpartition we wish to create. # This includes attributes that are required or have defaults. netpartition = { 'name': netpartition_name } # Add optional attributes to the message. if netpartition_id: netpartition['tenant_id'] = netpartition_id with self._neutron_exceptions( "Error creating netpartition " "{0}".format(netpartition_name)): new_netpartition = self.manager.submitTask( _tasks.NetpartitionCreate(body=dict(net_partition=netpartition))) return new_netpartition['net_partition'] def delete_netpartition(self, name_or_id): """Delete a netpartition. If a name, instead of a unique UUID, is supplied, it is possible that we could find more than one matching netpartition since names are not required to be unique. An error will be raised in this case. :param name_or_id: Name or ID of the netpartition being deleted. :returns: True if delete succeeded, False otherwise. :raises: OpenStackCloudException on operation error. """ netpartition = self.get_netpartition(name_or_id) if not netpartition: self.log.debug("Netpartition %s not found for deleting" % name_or_id) return False with self._neutron_exceptions( "Error deleting netpartition {0}".format(name_or_id)): self.manager.submitTask( _tasks.NetpartitionDelete(netpartition=netpartition['id'])) return True ipv6_ra_mode=None, ipv6_address_mode=None, net_partition=None): :param string net_partition: The name of the Neutron net-partition. if net_partition: subnet['net_partition'] = net_partition

commit_message:
WIP Crazy Patch involving metaclass

We all know that you should never use metaclasses. Except when you
should. Maybe this is one of those rare times? But it probably isn't.

Change-Id: If8c4fac53d42e7f11f886683b7d18c76cc1bf6f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/08/241808/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import abcclass CloudMetaClass(type): def __init__(cls, name, bases, dct): for task_name, task in _tasks.__dict__.items(): if not isinstance(task, abc.ABCMeta): continue if task_name in dct: task_name = '_{task_name}'.format(task_name=task_name) def caller(self, *args, **kwargs): try: return self.manager.submitTask(task(*args, **kwargs)) except OpenStackCloudException: raise except Exception as e: if '__error__' in task.__dict__: raise OpenStackCloudException( task.__error__.format(**kwargs) + str(e)) else: raise OpenStackCloudException(str(e)) caller.__name__ = task_name setattr(cls, task_name, caller) __metaclass__ = CloudMetaClass

commit_message:
Add CRUD methods for keystone groups

This replaces review Ia25b76c38c3463c963a5ac2ae1c81fcd33dc591b.

Change-Id: I9a6a28994d076f032fe27624cdb3b0fbe248acef
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/33/242633/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """ test_groups ---------------------------------- Functional tests for `shade` keystone group resource. """ import shade from shade.tests import base class TestGroup(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestGroup, self).setUp() self.cloud = shade.operator_cloud(cloud='devstack-admin') if self.cloud.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') in ('2', '2.0'): self.skipTest('Identity service does not support groups') self.group_prefix = self.getUniqueString('group') self.addCleanup(self._cleanup_groups) def _cleanup_groups(self): exception_list = list() for group in self.cloud.list_groups(): if group['name'].startswith(self.group_prefix): try: self.cloud.delete_group(group['id']) except Exception as e: exception_list.append(str(e)) continue if exception_list: # Raise an error: we must make users aware that something went # wrong raise shade.OpenStackCloudException('\n'.join(exception_list)) def test_create_group(self): group_name = self.group_prefix + '_create' group = self.cloud.create_group(group_name, 'test group') for key in ('id', 'name', 'description', 'domain_id'): self.assertIn(key, group) self.assertEqual(group_name, group['name']) self.assertEqual('test group', group['description']) def test_delete_group(self): group_name = self.group_prefix + '_delete' group = self.cloud.create_group(group_name, 'test group') self.assertIsNotNone(group) self.assertTrue(self.cloud.delete_group(group_name)) results = self.cloud.search_groups(filters=dict(name=group_name)) self.assertEqual(0, len(results)) def test_delete_group_not_exists(self): self.assertFalse(self.cloud.delete_group('xInvalidGroupx')) def test_search_groups(self): group_name = self.group_prefix + '_search' # Shouldn't find any group with this name yet results = self.cloud.search_groups(filters=dict(name=group_name)) self.assertEqual(0, len(results)) # Now create a new group group = self.cloud.create_group(group_name, 'test group') self.assertEqual(group_name, group['name']) # Now we should find only the new group results = self.cloud.search_groups(filters=dict(name=group_name)) self.assertEqual(1, len(results)) self.assertEqual(group_name, results[0]['name']) def test_update_group(self): group_name = self.group_prefix + '_update' group_desc = 'test group' group = self.cloud.create_group(group_name, group_desc) self.assertEqual(group_name, group['name']) self.assertEqual(group_desc, group['description']) updated_group_name = group_name + '_xyz' updated_group_desc = group_desc + ' updated' updated_group = self.cloud.update_group( group_name, name=updated_group_name, description=updated_group_desc) self.assertEqual(updated_group_name, updated_group['name']) self.assertEqual(updated_group_desc, updated_group['description'])

commit_message:
Return volume_type extra specs based on policy

Currently extra specs are only shown to the admin user
when showing volume types. This patch grants the flexibility
to grant other users privelages to see them based on policy.

It also hides the extra_specs entry in the dictionary from
users who can't see it rather than just showing "None" as
the value.

Closes-Bug: #1504577
APIImpact

Change-Id: Ia8f71180f048ba9b253e35ee136915812ef8df0c

commit_message:
Adjust object_store to use upload/download names

object_store had been using create_object and save_object names, but
we've previously aggreed to use upload and download for those types of
calls.

Change-Id: I59a17cc29a989096820093ac7e6dba87c1f58b66
Partial-Bug: #1488631

commit_message:
Add doc tool chain

Various tox env are defined (borrowed from openstack-manuals),
The following are part of such tox envs:
- docs
- checkbuild
- checkniceness
- generatepot-rst

For mainly a testing purpose, contributor-guide/source/index.rst
includes CONTRIBUTING.rst at the top level.
To generate the current doc, run "tox -e checkbuild".

Change-Id: I5eb67c4d75fcbfba766c87664d0d0a33e7b89029

Since it's installed in the system, let's # use sitepackages. sitepackages=True whitelist_externals = doc-tools-check-languages commands = doc-tools-check-languages doc-tools-check-languages.conf test all [testenv:buildlang] # Run as "tox -e buildlang -- $LANG" # Generatedocbook needs xml2po which cannot be installed # in the venv. Since it's installed in the system, let's # use sitepackages. sitepackages=True whitelist_externals = doc-tools-check-languages bash commands = doc-tools-check-languages doc-tools-check-languages.conf test {posargs} # Check that .po and .pot files are valid: bash -c "find doc -type f -regex '.*\.pot?' -print0|xargs -0 -n 1 msgfmt --check-format -o /dev/null" [testenv:publishlang] # Generatedocbook needs xml2po which cannot be installed # in the venv. Since it's installed in the system, let's # use sitepackages. sitepackages=True whitelist_externals = doc-tools-check-languages commands = doc-tools-check-languages doc-tools-check-languages.conf test all [testenv:docs] commands = # Build and copy RST Guides {toxinidir}/tools/build-all-rst.sh [testenv:generatepot-rst] # Generate POT files for translation, needs {posargs} like: # tox -e generatepot-rst -- contributor-guide commands = {toxinidir}/tools/generatepot-rst.sh i18n 1 {posargs} [doc8] # Settings for doc8: # This file has extra long lines that cannot be avoided, let's white list it. ignore-path = .tox,test-requirements.txt # File extensions to use extensions = .rst,.txt # Disable some doc8 checks: # D000: Check RST validity (cannot handle lineos directive) ignore = D000

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-05 23:35:59.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/objects/test_block_device.py', 'nova/objects/block_device.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9540c813d3d38e9ea5dba5369fc8f3165834a76a', 'message': "cells: create bdm at top if device_name is set for first time in save()

does the following:

3. Snapshot the volume-backed server instance.
4. Boot a second server from the snapshot image.

The second server boot fails because the snapshot image has duplicate

being turned into two volume snapshots in step 3 above.
